div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamers leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE DUMA ELECTIONS.
div.p: In little more than five weeks the new Duma will be sitting in St. Petersburg, and in some of the villages the elections have already begun. The Continental Press, which is not favourable to the Russian Bureaucracy, is filled with stories of the way in which the Government is tampering, and is preparing to tamper, with the elections. It is accused of favouring by every means in its power the candidates of the Right, namely, the League of the Russian People, the Union of Law and Order, and the Octobrists, and of paralysing and disorganising the parties of the Opposition. The lists of voters are filled up irregularly, newspapers are suppressed, meetings of elec- tors are forbidden, and suspects are marched oft to Siberia by the hundred. The Government has completely regained the upper hand in the provinces, and is taking care that a "good" Duma, as the phrase goes, shall be returned. Had the St. Petersburg officials not been too proud to learn from Servia and Bulgaria, they might have secured a proper majority in the first Duma, but there is now every sign that the methods of those States have been studied and carefully laid to heart. It is rather sur- prising that Russia should ever have allowed the little Slav States at its door to possess elected houses, for the example must necesarily have been bad from the Bureaucratic point of view, but having allowed the creation of the Skuptschina, it would have been well also to have studied the Government methods of electing them. That has now apparently been done, and we may expect the new Duma to reflect the amount of skill which the Rus- sian officials have acquired in the manner in which elections in the minor Slav States are managed and controlled.

div.head: GERMAN TRADE IN TURKEY.
div.p: There was a time when English manufac- tures and goods held the first place in Turkey, and were approached by those of no other Power. But that is all changed now, and for some years past, Germany has been all power- ful at the Porte. A correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph," writing from Constantinople, gives several instances in which German contractors and financiers have been favoured to the ex- clusion of English and other non-German competitors. For this he gives two reasons, first, that the German Government works in complete accord with its national commerce, and any first-class firm can count on being backed to the utmost by the German Embassy. Secondly, that English finance and industry, finding themselves without support from the Government ,have gradually become dispirited, and have abandoned the field to their Teutonic rivals. The correspondent urges that our Am- bassador should strongly support our con- tractors and financiers in their endeavour to recover a share of the trade of Turkey, but he seems to overlook the fact that our diplomatists would urgfe in vain. The people really re- sponsible for the boycott of all things Eng- lish in Turkey are the fanatics who have never ceased to insult the Sultan and the Turks: the people who talk of "Abdul the Damned" and so on. The Turks are a slow race to rouse, but even they cannot be sup- posed to overlook the torrent of insults and invective poured out on them by the Exeter Hall crew.

div.head: Khedivial Ball.
div.p: The Khedivial Ball will be held at Abdeen Palace on the 28th proxo.

div.head: Crushed to Death.
div.p: A shore-porter was crushed to death yester- day in the harbour by the fall of a heavy bundle of wire on him.

div.head: Sallura and Soldiers' Institute
div.p: A lecture on "Alexandria" will be given by the Rev. Canon A. Ward at the above institute tomorrow (Wednesday) at 8.30 p.m.

div.head: Sudan Land and Commercial Company.
div.p: The Khedivial Decree authorising the establishment of the Sudan Land and Com- mercial Company will be issued shortly.

div.head: Irrigation Service
div.p: The Ministry of Publio Works intends to erect a new building for the Irrigation Service at Tantah, the cost of which has been estimated at L.E.7 000.

div.head: The Mog Cass.
div.p: Yesterday the Cairo Mixed Court of First Instance was to have given judgment in the case against the Egyptian Government brought by the heirs of the late Mog Pasha, but judg- ment was postponed for a fortnight,

div.head: Egyptiann Petroleum Co. Settlement.
div.p: Wednesday, February 6, has been fixed by the committes of the London Stock Exchange as a special setting day in Egyptian Petroleum Company, Limited—10,007 shares of £l each, 4s paid (Nos; 1 to 10,007)

div.head: The Sultan of Darfour.
div.p: Three of the emissaries of Ali Dinar, the Sultan of Dayfoor who were at Khartoum shopping for their master, have been despatched by the Sudan Government to Cairo to procure some sporting rifles and ammunition from tbh stores of the War Office tor the Su;tan. The emissaries, who arrived in Cairo on Sunday last will leave for Khartoum in two or three days.

div.head: Journalist Attempts Suicide.
div.p: M. Santorelli, managing editor of the 'Bos-phore Egyptien," tried to commit suicide by swallowing a does of corrosive sublimate in a bar near the Opera House at Cairo. He succeeded in imbibing part of the poison and would have effected his purpose but for the sudden interposition of a friend. The unfortunate man is still in a dangerous state and is suffering terriblo agony.

div.head: Posting Funeral Notices.
div.p: The Egyptian Poet Office is nothing if not resourceful. A notice just issued intimates that funeral notices may be posted in future at the central offices of Cairo and Alexandria and other towns for immediate special delivery. The cost of such delivery, in addition to ordinary postage, will be 200 piastres in Cairo and Alexandria, and 20 piastres elsewhere. Special delivery, however, will not be made in the suburbs.

div.head: French Comedy.
div.p: The French comedy company which has been performing with success at the Esbekieh Cardens Theatre,Cairo, for the last two months will give a series of 10 performances at the Alhambra, commencing on Thursday next. The company's repetoire includes : "Les Frauen Macone," 'L'enfaut du Miracle," "Florette et Pa'apon," "Les Surprises dn Divorce," "Plaidr d'Amour," ' Nelly Razier," "La D'Moiaelle de chez Maxim," ' L'Bufant Suruatiird," etc.

div.head: British Recreation Club
div.p: A smoking conrert will be held in the above club on Saturday next February 2, commencing at 9 p.m. As the committee have been successful in securing the assistance of many talented artists,this particular concert is likely to prove a record attraction, and it is hoped that the enterprise thus shown will meet with its due reward in a bumper attendance by members. A fancy dress ball will be held in the club on St Patrick's Eve, Saturday, March 16. Tickets (which include supper) may be obtained from the manager at P.T. 25 each. Dancing will commence at 9 p.m.

div.head: Burning a Bowab
div.p: The Greek who is accused by the Alexandria police authorities of having murdered a bowab by pouring petroleum over him while asleep, and then burning him to death, declares that he is not guilty of the crime. The victim. who expired in frightful agony, was able before his death to make a declaration to the effect that the accused, who is named Alexander Maschas, perpetrated the crime. Maschas is a storekeeper employed ly Messrs. Tadros Uhirgis and Son, of Alexandria. He is 45 years ot age. The dossier of the case was sent this morning to the Hellenic consular authorities from the Gouvernorat.

div.head: An Eoho.
div.p: We read in the "Matin" of January 10, 1907, the following:—M. Tronillot, ex Minister of Commerce, who presided at the Commercial Corgress of the "Matin," delivered yesterday a discourse in London which was much applauded, on the occasion of the inauguration of the new branch of the Berlitz Schools for the instruction of French. The King was officially represented by a member of the Royal family. This is a proof of how esteemed the celebrated schools of languages are, and their success increases every day. [Advt.]

div.head: DEPARTURE FOR SIWA OASIS.
div.p: The Khedive came down to Alexandria yesterday evening from Cairo. To-day his Highness leaves for Mariout, and thence will go on a trip in the Western desert, acompanied by 14 officials of the Khedivial Palace and Kbaasa, and 35 of a Cavalry guard. His Highness. who will go as far as the Siwa Ossis, will spend three weeks on his trip, being expected to return to Cairo on the 18th proxo. The Khedive received Lord Cromer in private audience at Koubbeh Palace on Sunday.

div.head: THE BAD WEATHER.
div.p: SHIPS DELAYED

Terrible weather has been prevailing in the Mediterranean, and the regular passenger steamers are delayed. The Messageies Maritime S S Niger, which was due at Alexandria from Marseilles this morning, has not yet arrived. The steamer was not even signalled as having passed through the Straits of Messins, which fact is usnally notified to the Alexandria office of the Messageries Maritime Company, but this may have been due to the fact that she passed though the Straits at night. The North German Lloyd's S.S Schleswig, which was due at Alexandria from Marseilles yesterday, has not arrived, and up to the time of our going to press has not been signalled.

div.head: AL AZHAR.
div.p: Sheikh Hassnna El Nawawi has been ap- pointed Chanoellor. of Al Azhar. Yesterday afternoon the sheikh was received in audience by the Khedive, to whom he tendered his thanks for the appointment

div.head: JUDICIAL CHANGES.
div.p: The "Lewa" mentions Ahnred Bey Afifi as the likely sucessor of Basili Pasha Tadro , who retires from the presidency of the Mixed Court of Appeal. According to the same authority, Yehia Bey Ibrahim will succeed Saleh Paaba Sabet as President of the Native Court of Appeal.

div.head: NEW RAILWAYS IN EGYPT.
div.p: The London correspondent of the "Birmingham postt" writes :— It is understood that, in the course of next week, very elaborate plans and estimates for the new construction of new railways in Egypt and the Sudan will reach Whitehall from Cairo, accompanied by a despatch from Lord Cromer. Altogether, I believe, some 1,150 miles of new, line are proposed to be built, the cost being spread over the years 19 8-12; and, as there is now no likeli hood of opposition from any of the Powers represented on the Caisse de la Dette, it is assumed that the British Government will cordially endorse the proposals of the Anglo Egyptian authorities.

div.head: OTTOMAN FOUNDATION DAY.
div.p: On Sunday afternoon the Turks and Turcophiles of Cairo celebrated the 608th anniversary of the foundation of the Turkish Empire by Ottoman, at the Continental Hotel. Prince Haidar presided, and opened the festivities with a speech in French, in which he reviewed the sad situation in Turkey proper, owing to its bad government. Mustrapha Pasha Kamel, who followed, was less pessimistic. Speaking in Arabic, he alluded to the toleration of the Turkish people, and endeavoured to show that, from the standpoint of politics and religion, the Egyptians ought to take part in this festival. Djelaleddin Arif Bey, the lawyer, is an eloquent Turkish orator, and wound up an impassioned appeal with an invocation of all Ottomans to unite to resonate Turkey from her threatened ruin. Pierre Loti was an honoured guest, but did not venture to voice his opinions ; possibly the author of "Disenchanted" felt that the matter had been sufficiently dealt with by such a flood of eloquence. He was, however, made much of, and hailed "ami intime" by Kamel. The party then adjourned to the buffet, and did full justice to its viands.

div.head: NEW BOURSE REGUALTIONS
div.p: The committees of the Cairo and Alexandria Boorses have been granted a grace expiring on the 15th February, so as to study the new regulations and express opinions thereon, to be submitted to the International Judicial Commission, which will meet immediately afterwards.

div.head: THE RUSSIAN AFFAIR.
div.p: PRISONERS SMUGGLED ON BOARD.

Yesterday evening the armed guard, which the authorities of the Alexandria Gouvernorat had stationed at the Russian Consulate, was withdrawn, as the Commandant of Police and the Russian Consol consider that there is no farther danger of any outrage being attempted. There are still a number of detectives in the immediate neighbourhood of the consulate keeping watch lest some unex- pected assault should be made, and any suspicious-looking individual approaching the con- sulate is carefuly scrutinised. Some strange tales have been bruited about in the local Press as to the position and careers of the three Russians. A Cairo newspaper declared that one of the men was a Georgian prince of the name of Mitchikwadze, who was a prominent member of the Russian Socialist party and had assassinated no less than fifty- eight Russian officials before he left his native land. These and such-like stories are pure inventions. The three men were individuals belonging to the lower orders. One was an old sailor who had not done any work for some time, another was a house painter by trade, while the third was a young man who is known to have passed through three classes of a lower grade school but had no claim to be considered a person of education. The arrival of the three Russian prisoners in Port Said passed quite unpercieved by the populace, abd the men were embarked with such swiftness that the news had not time to spread about the town. The Russian S.S Korniloff was uuder steam when the train with the prisoners arrived, and they were hurried on board without a moment's delay.

div.head: A CURIOUS COINCIDENCE.
div.p: A remarkable plot, very similar to that of which the three Russians arrested here are accused, has been disoovered at the Pireans. The Athenian newspaper "Akropolis," of the 26th inst., announces that two Russian Jews embarked as passengers on board the Russian merchantman S.S. Mark at the Piraeus for Odessa. One of the two men, whose name is Ivan Velinski, was found by the captain of the ship to have in his possession two bombs and other explosive material. He and his friends were arrested by the captain ard handed over to the Russian man-of-war Ma-vrotb'achasetes, which is at the Pireaus. An official enquiry was opened, and both the men confessed that they were Anarchists. Ivan declared that he intended to blow up the ship after it had left the port. He stated that he was quite willing to sacrifice his life in order to effect his purpose.

div.head: NILE NAVIGATION.
div.p: The Nile Navigation Commission have decided that navigation shall follow the small branch of the Nile west of Ghezireh Isle. To do this, the Babr El Ahmar is to be dredged. The northern part of the island has been handed over to the Government by the Central African Mission, which will recieve in exchange lands farther south. The spit of land so acquired by the Government will be cut awat, and thus free the river. By these changes the new Abbas Bridge will cross the river with one span so that traffic between Ghezireh and Cairo will be uninterrupted. The Lion Bridge, which will be closed, will probably be enlarged. The Irrigation Servine has decided to constrcut a sadd across the Rosetta branch of the Nile at Mehallet el Amir, kilometre 215 down- stream of the Delta Barrage. Navigation on the Rosetta branch of the Nl'e will be interrupted by the above mention-ed place during such time as the sadd will be maintained there. The Irrigation Service reminds the public that it is not permissible for any craft to circulate on the Rosetta and Bermnsi canals, which are not navigatble waterways. A part of the above-mentioned sadd will be specially affected to transhipment of goods arriving on boats. Tge transhipment will be carried out at the risk, peril, expense, and care of the owners of the boats or goods. The sadd will be closed about 10th March, and will be removed about 15th August.

div.head: SEISMOLOGICAL SATIONS IN EGYPT.
div.p: In view of the Jamaica upheaval, it is in- teresting to note that seismological stations have recently been established by the British Association Committee at Beyrout and Cairo. The permanent committee of the International Seismological Association has decided to assemble in future every two years; and a meeting of the association will be held next September at The Hague. At present Great Britain and France have not officially joined the association, but it is understood that a re- presentation to the Treasury has been made by the Royal Society as to the desirability of having Great Britian permanently represented in the seismological Association.

div.head: FRANCE AND ABYSSINIA.
div.p: M. KLOBUKOWSKI'S MISSION.

We understand that M. Klobnkowski, French Diplomatic Agent, on his return to Cairo from Paris, will confer with Lord Cromer before starting for Adis Abeha. M. Klobnkowski's mission in Abyssinia will be of four months' duration. He will be accompanied by M. de Revrraeaox who is. we believe, the son of the famous French Ambassdor at Vienna. On the termination of M. Kloknkowski's mission in Abyssinia a successor to M. Lagarde will be appointed.

div.head: GERMANS IN TURKEY.
div.p: ANOTHER CONCESSION.

Significant of the commercial success of the Germans at Constantinople is a private report to hand to the effect that after ten years' endeavours German contractors have received an Irade for the construction of a new bridge between Stamboul and Pera, at a cost of L.T. 200,000. The funds are provided by the Deutsche Bank, Berlin.

div.head: ELECTRIC LIGHT FOR STAMBOUL.
div.p: Oar Stamboul contemporaries announced that Constantinople is to be lighted by electricity. H I.M. the Saltan has issued an Irade virtue of which gas is to be replaced by electricity in Galata, Pera, Shishli, Beshiktash, and the vil- lages on the European shore of the Bosphorus. The concession for the eleotric lighting has been granted to the Ordnance Department, and the convention relating to it is being prepared at the Ministry of Public Works. The Ordnance Department is authorized to supply power for industrial purposes. Thus far, electricity—an attribute of Satan —was banned in sacred Stamhoul. The only power station was at Haidar Pasha, accross the Straits.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN FINANCE AND EXCHANGE CO., LTD.
div.p: We will publish in a few days' time the prospectus of the Anglo-Egyptian Finance and Exchange Company, Limited. It is based on very sound principles and has been drawn up with a view to ensuring the maximum efficiency of the company. There are no founders,' preference, or deferred shares, and this fact will greatly enhance the value of the shares of the company. No less than two-thirds of the entire capital of the com-pany have already been subscribed so that there will be a very small balance for public subscription. The Anglo Egyptian Finance and Exchange Company, Limited, will be floated early next month. This is an Egyptian company, but all the board of directors and the management will be in Egypt. The capital will be £200.000, of which only £67,000 will be offered for public subscription, as the balance of the capital has already all been taken up by the memorandum of association. There are 200,000 ordinary shares of £1 each, and there has been no underwriting commission. The main objects of the company are to carry on business as bankers, stock and share brokers, etc., in Cairo, Alexandria and elsewhere. The subscription will be opened at the Anglo- Egyptian Bank at Cairo, Alexandria, and the provincial branches on the 7th and 8th proxo. There is already a premium of five-eighths on the shares, which are being dealt in private- ly at that price.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MAIL STEAMSHIP CO., LTD.
div.p: The prospectus of the Egyptian Mail Steam- ship Company, Limited, appears to have evoked some criticism among financial authorities in London, especially as to the premium. The "Statist" remarks: "It will naturally be under- stood that much depends upon the management and the issue can only be regarded as a decidedly speculative one, and why the premium of £1 per share?" "Public Opinion" says :— One of the most impudent attempts of re-cent years to raise funds at the expense of the investing public is that now being made by the Egyptian Mail Steamship Company, Ltd. The company proposes to establich what it terms a "line" of steamships between Europe and Egypt. Such "line" is to consist of—not ten or six or even foor, but—two steamers. Neither one is yet built, and presumably delivery cannot be obtained until the public have furnished the money to pay the builders. The contract price is £606,000, which seems a pretty stiff figure. Admitting, however, that the price is no more than the ships are worth, does it not seem ridiculous that a publics company thould be formed to carry on a shipping business with only two vessels, either of which or both may be lost or damaged so as to be unnavigable? Of course, the boats will be insured, but in the event of the con- tingency referred to the revenue of the com- pany would cease, and with it the dividends to the shareholders. There would be nothing to take their place—no reserve leet, as is the shipping companies with which we are familiar, and which have served the public so well, and paid their shareholders such good dividends. The most astonishing feature of the promoting, however that the shares are issued at a premium. What is the justification for this in the case of a business still in embryo?

div.head: NEW BULGRAIAN AGENT.
div.p: REFUSAL OF EXEQUATUR.

We gather that the refusal of the Porte to grant an exequatur to the new Bulgarian Agent at Cairo is due to two causes : the political dependence of Bulgaria on the Otto-man Empire and the absense of any consular convention between the vassal State and its suzerain. Bulgaria, be it remembered, is de jure a principality tributary to the Sultan. and it is not surprising that rights that would certainly be refused to Egypt have not been accorded to the Balkan Principality. De facto Bulgaria is independent: too independent perhaps from the Turkish point of view, but the legal situation of the vigorous little principality is that of a vassal state, and the Porte, which (at times) stands enormously on its dignity, is not likely to grant Bulgaria over many diplomatic con- cessions. M. Veroazza, who holds the position of Bulgarian Diplomatic Agent at Cairo, is moreover unlikely to obtain his exequatur, failing the conclusion of a consular convention between the two states, for the agreement betweenn M. Natchevich and the Porte did not we believe, impose on the Suzerain any obligation of the sort. The most probable solution of the difficulty is the recognition of M. Varnazza by a note or official letter from the Grand Vzier as commercial agent of the Principality of Bulgaria, though we fancy that the new addition to the Diplomatic Body will act, if and when necessary, as a Consul General.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: "ZAZA."

Opera may conceivably be divided into two categories : those to which the plot is incidental to the music and those wherein the music is dependent upon the plot; an adaptation of a play usually comes w thin the latter province. Thus, in the case of "Zaza," one gets a result so crowded with incident that there is little scope for enlargement or for exercise of the imagination. It is like a Burlington Arcade shop with nothing to back up the display in the window. As a play "Zaza" had, of course, a big success in Mme Rejane's hands and created something of a furore in London after miraculously having passed the censor. The action turns upon the love of Zaza, a music- hall singer, for Dufresne, but, after succeeding in winning his affection, she is horrified at the discovery that he is a married man. Finding out his address she madly rushes there, but confronted with his little daughter, the fury of her disappointment is turned to compuction at being the cause of roin to his household. Sobbing and heartbroken, she returns and, at their next meeting, Dufresne learns to his despair of her secret visit and forthwith abandons her. Here the opera ends, while the comedy has another act in which Dufresne, after a prolonged absence, tries to regain his former place in "Zaza's" affections. The opera is scored in Leoncavallo's usual easy style, and, apart from one or two good romances, notably that of Dufresne in Act III, contains nothing very striking or original. However, it is always pleasant and "unan-strengend," and had the advantage of being very well produced last night. It depended cheifly for its success on Signa. Livia Berlendi in the title ro'e, and we congratulate her : upon a remarkably fine achievement. Her voice, acting, and appearance were all that they should be. The rapid contrasts between joy gand grief (Act II ) and between rage and remorse (Act III) were particularly well ex- pressed. As Dutresne, Sig. Acerbi sang with considerable effect, but the part calls for greater histrionic talent than is his. A word should be said for the pretty manner in which little Miss Finzi spoke her lines. The house was crowded, and enthusiastically applauded what was undoubtedly a very pleasing per- formance. In the first entrancte a small fire occurred in the adjoining exhibition of Sig.Rossi's pictures, and we fear some of these dainty works have been destroyed. Tbe onbreak was, how- ever, promptly extinguished, and passed practi-cally unnoticed.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Saad Pasha Zighloul visited H.E. the Prime Minister at Mena on Sunday dead Pasha's tour of inspection in Upper Egypt does not seem to have wearied him in the least, and we hear rumours of fresh inspections in the Delta.

Pierre Loti, the well known French writer, was received by the Khedive at Konhbeh before his Highness left Cairo. The Khedive knew Commandant Viand at Constantinople, where he was twice presented to his Highness by M. Constant, the French Ambassador.
Sir John and Lady Evans are coming to Egypt They will also pay a visit to the Sudan, and do not expect to return to England until after Easter.
We regret to announce the death which took place at Alexandria this morning, of Dr. George Stopovich Bey, the Ottoman Sanitary Delegate in Egypt.

Mr Hornsby. the manager of the National Bark of Egypt at Alexandria, is shortly to be transferred to Cairo to a new post. which has been created at the hank. He title will be "Directeur General1 de la Comptabilite," and it will carry with it seniority below the subgovernors and above the managers.
M.Emmanual Kamaras,director of the Athens branch of the Orient Bank, and Mme Kamaras have arrived in Cairo, and are expected here next week
The salary of Marc Bey Bialobos, controller of the Financial Secretary's Department, has been raised to L.E. 960 per annim.

Lord Kitchener's recent accident might have been most serious, but he must be getting pretty well inured to accidents by thie time. There was a certain explosion of a mine at Chatham, one remembers, which permanently injured his right eye and condemned him to the use of pince-nez whenever he pores over maps and charts. At the battle of Suakin, again, a hostile bullet broke his jaw, and still embedded somewhere despite several painful operations with the purposee of extracting it. His lordship fraotored his leg shortly after his arrival in India.

But perhaps Lord Kitchener's most excting adventure happened in Palestine while he was engaged with Major Condor in the survey of that country The surverying party were swamped at Safed in Galilee when a horde of fanatical Moslems attacked them. Kitchener had nothing but his cane to defend himself with, and when the tussle was over he turned up covered with blood, having had a narrow escape from a negro who bad attempted to cleave him with a huge scimitar. Malarial fever followed, and for the first time in his life, they say, 'K. of K." gave way to his emotion by yelling, one burning afternoon. "For the Lord's sake, give me some of that beer!"

Major William J. Marshall. V C., who is retiring from the post of Camp Quartermaster at Aldershot, won the Victoria Cross by a notable act of bravery during the Sudan campaign of 1884. The incident, occured in the memorable calvary charge at El Teb, where Lient.-Col. Barrow, commanding the 19th Hussars, was severely wounded, and with his horse killed, was lying on the ground surrounded by the dervishes. Major Marshall (then Quarter- master Sergeant) remained with his chief throughout the action, and at an opportune moment seized Colonel Barrow by the hand and dragged him safety through the enemy back to his regiment.
Major Marshall had previously seen active service in the Egyptian War, being present at the battle of Tel-el Kebir. He took part in the defence of Ladysmith during the South African campaign.

div.head: SIR B. STONE ON EGYPTIAN MANNERS.
div.p: Sir Benjamin Stone, who is not visting Egypt, in a letter to a correspondent, says :— "I may in a few words express surprise and regret at the publication of alarmist paragraphs respecting the behaviour of natives towards visitors. After a return here after some years, I can appreciate the distince improvement in courtesy and manners of the Egyptian people, a significant sign of contentment and prosperity which is correctly attributed to the wise guidence of the governing authorities, and particualrly to the to the wise counsels of Lord Cromer."

div.head:
THE GERMAN ELECTIONS.
CHEIF GAINS AND LOSSES

div.p: The chief party gains and looses are: Conservatives, 7 seats gained, 2 lost ; Imperialists, 2 and 4; Liberale, 9 and 9 ; Radicals, 4 and 2 ; Centra, 2 and 4; Poles, 2 seats gained; Guelphs. 3 seats lost ; Socialists, 1 gained and 20 lost. In many constituences while one party definitely lost a seat, it is uncertain which other party will win it in second ballot, heince the inequality of the present totals of losses and gains. Herr Dernbnrg, in the course of an interview, stated that the attitude of the Centre towards the Colonies had lost its significance, as a majority was now secured without it. While this is possibly true in a general sense, the co-operation of the Radicals and Conservatives is most unlikely. The former will probably remain an opposition party: to most purposes the Centre will thus still hold the balance. (Reuter)

Prince de Radolin, speaking at a banquet given here on the occasion of the Emperor William's birthday, said that nothing now hindered or dial relations between France aud Germany. The result of the elections was the finest birthday present to the Emperor from his people. (Reuter)
Te American and German commissioners have arranged a complete basis for a commercial treaty. (Reuter)

Mr. Bryce, speaking at a farewell banquet at which he was entertained in Manchester, said that Anglo-American relations were never so good. This was evidenced by the Swettenbam incident, which once would have been the sig- nal for cries of defiance in the press of both countries. He paid a tribute to the lofty and broad spirit which inspired Mr. Root's speech. (Reuter)
A general thaw has set in all over Great Britain. (Reuter)
The Chamber has dissolved on the expiration of its mandate. (Havas)
A terrific rainstorm, lasting 10 minutes, played havoc with the local shipping here. A hundred Chinese lost their lives. British,warships rescued many. (Reuter)
Switzerland has nominated Artillery Colonel Muller as Inspector General of the Moroccan police. (Reuter)

div.head:
ITALIAN CONSUL FOR THE SUDAN.
A NEW DEVELOPMENT.
div.p: The Cairo Correspondent of the ''Pall Mall Gazette" says : —

Cavalière Carle Rossetti is about to proceed to Khartoum to take up his appointment as Italian Consul. This is, indeed, a new develop- ment. The Sudan ever since its reconquest has been under strict martial law, and, according to Article X. of the Anglo-Egyptian Condominium, signed on January 19,1899, no Consuls, Vice-Consuls, or Consular Agents were to be accredited in respect of or allowed to reside in the Sudan without the previous consent of the British Government. This consent has up to now been most steadfastly refused, just as was the case with the permission of the setting up of missions. But the Sudan has progressed so much, and in such a peaceful way, that all such prohibitions can with safety be relaxed now, and I understand that the appointment of an Italian Consul at Khartoum will shortly be followed by the nomination of an Austrian, and perhaps a Greek one. If 1 am not mistaken, the last Consul accredited to the Sudan was the Austrian Consul. Hansal, who was in Khartonm with Gordon, and whom Slatin Pasha mentions in "Fire and Sword in the Sudan." The introduction of foreign Consul into the Sudan will fortunately not entail the exercise of the capitulations. The latter are only in force in the countries which owe allegiance to the Sultar, and the Sudan is certainly not one of there latter. It is entirely under an Anglo-Egyptian administration, which in no wise is dependeut on Turkey. In, theory it is dependent on the British Agent in Cairo and the President of the Council of Ministes* of the Khedive ; but in practice, of course, he former controls through the Governor-General. One can positively assent that one of the potent factors in the speedy pacification of the Sudan, and, at all eveuts, the oue which has enabled the Governor-General, Sir Reginald Wingate, to achieve his work so well, has been the absence of interference of the capitualations in the maintenance of order, and there is no doubt that Lord Cromer showed considerable foresight and an appreciation of the difficulties when l.e laid down in the agreement ot January 19, 1899, that not even the jurisdiction of the Mixed Tribunals should be extended or recoguised in the Sadan.

div.head: HELOPOLIS OASIS
div.p: We have just paid a visit to the oases in the desert of Abbassieh, and, truth to tell, we marvelled at all there was to see. When one considers that scarcely eight months ago this part of the desert, situated to the east of Konbbeb and north of the old Suez road, was an arid waste, and that it is now marked out with long, broad avenues, with here and there a gigantic hotel, a restaurant and bar, villas, water mains, in a word, a garden city, all this in course of construction and almost finished, one wonders whether some magician or other has not touched the land with his magic wand to make it produce the great modern city which is now taking shape. Magic, however, plays no part in this metamorphosis : it is the work of a devouring human activity placed at the service of a concious will. A visit to the spot will reveal the legion of engineers, surveyors, contractors, draughtsmen, foreman, and workmen carrying out under the vigilant eye of an able management those many works accomplished daily by over 2,500 work- men for account of the Cairo Electric Railways and Heliopolis Oasis Company. Formed on the 23rd January, 1906. it took over from Bogho Pasha Nubar and Baron Empain the concessions for the electric railways and tramways which are to connect the oases with Cairo, and the ownership of an estate covering twenty-five squaree kilometres, ie, 5,952 fad- dans, north-east of the Po'ygon of Abbassieh and bought from the Government for £1 per feddan. The railway and tramway concessions extend over a period of seventy years, after which they revert to the Government with all appurtenances. The land itself, of course, remains the property of the company, and the agreement of the 23rd May 1905, reserves to it the right, within a period of seven years, to purchase on the same terms as mentioned above i.e., £1 per feddan, a stretch of desert twice the size of the one which the company already possesses, viz., 11,904 feddans, for the purpose of creating other oases. It is to be noted that the Company has abundant means at its disposal. Its capital amounts to 15,000,000 francs, which may be increased to 30,000,000 by decision of the board of directors. The capital is divided into 60,000 Ordinary shares of 250 francs each and 60,000. Deferred shares of nominal value. Only 10,000 Ordinary shares were offered to the public. The, board of the company is composed of Baron E louard E npa'n (chairman), Boghos Pasha Nubar and Lord Armstrong (vice-chairmen), Me-srs. Berthelot, Carton de Wiart, François Empain, Col. Sir Augustus FitzGeorge, Todd Symons, Sir John Rogers Pasha, aud Jacobs, (directors) while the managing director is Sir Reginald Oakes. It may be said that the ides of creating close to Cairo large airy subrybs where side by side with dwellings which fufuils every demand of modern comfort people will find all that contributes to facilitate the conditions of living and render life more attractive, is due to the actual conditions of living in the capital. The rentals within recent years, have attained absurd proportions, and the dearth of suitable houses is felt more than ever. The 'vox populi" demanded susomething more and better. The Cairo Electric Railways and Helio-polis Oaises Company cans just in time to realise the great work needed, and the creation of the oases of the desert of Abbassieh war thereupon decided. The site chosen, in the im mediate vicinity of Cairo, makes it very attractive. It is situated 50 metres above sea level and practically dominates Cairo and the Pyramids. Its altitude, which is higher than Koubbeh or Matarieh (as the desert stretches from the cultivated lands on which the eastern suburbs of Cairo are placed and mounts gradually towards the hills which form the spurs of the Mokattam), makes it one of the healthiest spots about Cairo. Doubtless Cairo residents during the summer season will fleek there, and many of the British officers quartered at Abbassieh will take up the villas which are to be built. Only one difficulty stood in the way of making the oases popular, and that was the great distance from the centre of Cairo, but this difficulty no longer exists since the company has obtained the 70 years' concession for the electric railway and tramway connecting the Oases with Cairo. trains on the railway will cover the distance between the Oases and Pont Limoun in 40 minute-; here the carriages will run partly on the Cario Tramway Company and He i -pol e Oi-es Company and partly on those of the Cairo Tramway Company, thus transporting passengers without any change to the centre of the capital. Thus great work is being pushed on with admirable activity by the Heliopoilis Company, and we hope to give further particulars as to the progress of the undertaking in a few days.

div.head: OPERA IN CAIRO.
div.p: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
"LES HUGUENOTS."
(From our Theatrical Correspondent.)

"The Huguenots" was, in performance, as in its own nature, pompous, pretentions, rather vague, yet with moments of real beauty. Mme. Baron, now and again, M. Mézy, and M. M were good enough—but only now and again. Mile. Davilloy was faautless and delightful, M. Mézy was never quite on his note ; and for that matter M. Maas himself was far less certain and accurate than usual. M. Fontaine attempted the tenor part. He sang with taste, and acted well. He generally does that ; but his voice was inadequate : the high notes were an effort, and—listened to dispassionately— they sounded trying, forced, vociferous rather than musical ; the lowar notes and softer passages were strangled to the last degree. He did not seem to have real tenor's command over anything but "forte" or "fortissimo." But once and for all it is the same story for the whole of this company. They are "thereabouts," but never "there." They give some good acting, some fine tones and notes, but Dover a real workmanlike finish : they never have the mastery of the piece except for three, Escalais, Darand, and Charpentier. Mila. Charpentier may not always be in good voice, but she always sings as a professional should. M. Da rand may be past his best, but he is always accurate, exact, and thorough. M. Escalais may displease many who think he only shoots (he often does!) but he sings in the manner and with the ease of a grand opera singer : to the worst criticism one might give— long power, one must add, lung power well directed. The rest, as well as the orchestra and chorus, seem as if they had never been properly directed or in any opera housee stringently controlled. One should be able to compare Cairo opera with that of the great cities ; instead of which we compare it, per- force, to opera of the provinces, and of travelling companies. No wonder! But then the prices should be lowered and a more honest and less impressive prospectus issued.

div.head: ABBAS THEATRE.
div.p: "OTELLO"

"The Italian company ran a great risk in taking "Otollo" as their opening piece. Apart from its associations with the greatest singers and theatres, it is a formidable opera in itself. ' hey would have done better to try "Tosca" first. It is early to pronounce on the performers, but one can at least say that Sig. Arrighetti (whose singing most of us disliked in the summer) was a complete surprise. He took I ago at the last moment, and though it hardly suits the range of his voice, he sang (and acted) quite well, and with a fine full tone. His aria in the 2nd act was indeed excellent. Signor Valls was by no means pleasing as Otello, either for his acting or for his singing. His voice is true to the note, but most unattractive. Signa Fabri was nervous at first, thin, and not always true to the note, but she improved and sang quite well in the last act. The rest were good enough after their kind. And what a relief to hear a good chourus and an excellent orchestra led by a really enthusiastic orchestraand a good room, but does that excuse its hopless discords and apathy in the theatre? Oh orchestras have played well enough here. One word One word I would venture-- from certain criticism I heard last night. It is hardly fair to judge the Abbas as if it were La Scala. I does not pretend to be. The Khedivial Theatre has glorious promises, high prices, and— we know its performances. Thoese who direct it must not be surprised if a disillusioned listener says what he thinks, and does make comparisons. Another word as to the chorus and their protects. Everyone recognises that it is far less their fault than that of the powers that be if they are a failure. Still, some of their fiascos were inexecusable on any grounds. To return to the Abbas : the house was crowded and most critical, rather unfavorable at moments ; but, as I said, the company took a great risk for their first night, and the performance was not perfect. I am sure they will do many of the operas really well, and equally sure hat they will be fairly judged, and fully praised for all the is good. finish bars at the fall of the curtain. They did se last night : such a critical spirit deserves its reward in real effort on the part of the performers ; and I believe that in the operas that suit them, perhaps in all the repertoire (once they are acclimated), they will make the effort with success. At least, 1 am sure we all wish them that success : it is quite likely they will achieve it in "Tosca."
'LA TOSCA."

"La Tosca" was a real pleasure. Italy seems so prolific in sopranos, tenors, and conductors, and they all seem to have "Tosca" in the blood. I have not yet seen a perform in whichsome part or some singer was not really good. On Friday night it was—almost all- very good. Perhaps the only fault was that once or twcoe Sig. Campanini seemed to smother his violines : the " 'cellos " were so prominent in one place—at 'Senti l'ora é vicina'- (3rd act), as to ronghen and almost break up the movement of tha music, and the music of "Tosca" suffers from that. Heard for the first time it repels, then from its curious strength, its approach to savagery, its rapid passion and eagerness for love or death, it attracts and finally conquers. The whole scheme is so primitive, as primitive and earnest as a Huguenot chorale : people who can love, who can kill, who can believe are amongst this world's eter- nities ; and the music which expresses them, should, once it can conqner our modern practical apathy, be also eternal, sounding a dim echo within our own emotions. To return to 'La Tosca," Signora Orbellini and Signor Tachierdo were both delightfal. Her entry and all her singing and actiug in the first act were all one could hope for, replete with the most minate touches of tenderness, malice, reproach, scorn—but the polite scorn of a diva for an old "viveur." Her seoand act was rather to0 violent. I heard Pandolfini and Ballinoioui in it. Pandolfini was, and will be believe, always for those who heard her, "La Tosca" incarnate, as ' La Tosca" must have been. Bellinoioni seemed to be one of the cleverest women who ever studied the part—but transformed it. In the 3rd act; Signs. Orbelliai was again perfect in everything, and her partner was nearly so. His great song 'E lnoevan le stelle" was admirable. The opening, "O dolci mani," was a delight ; but he borders on convention, and he has not always finish ; thire are moments of uncertainty and too muoh individuality. But his voice is charming, and has that openness and distance of clear tone one longs for in a lyric tenor. Sig. Arri- ghetti was quite a good Scarpia, but his voioe seems unsuitable, as it did sometimes in "Otello." He does not command all his notes. The chorus and orchestra were excellent and true, but Campanini was often too hard on his singers. The house was packed, as on Thursday, and, I understand, Satarday night. If that continues, they will be al'e to afford one or two more really good singers, and to "sarry off' these operas which at present would seem rather above their powers. At least we can remember that Signor Battani is one of the company.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITIOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair place to al, to permit- within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: A TOURIST'S COMPLAINT.
div.p: To the Editor of the 'Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,—We tourists have a good deal to be thankful for, in view of the excessive cold all over Europe, in finding ourselves in Egypt, although even here it is by no means warm. However, this is not what I wish to write about. Some days ago when at Assiout it was so bitterly cold that no amount of pestering on the part of the donkey boys or drivers muster- ed on Cook's landing stags, woauld overcome our persuasion to go for a sharp walk, thinking it the only means of warming our hitherto frozen bodies. On inquiry, the dragoman informed us that there was a lovely promenade on thr front, with gardens, etc, and we had no difficulty in following his instructions. The part was indeed unexpectedly pretty with the Coptic palaces as a background, but alas ! for the loveliness of ths promenade. I had not gone far when I fell on my side, spraining my ankle. The roughness and stones strewn abont made it painful to proceed, we hailed a vehicle and returned to our steamer, where I had to lay up. We have been wondering how the inhabitants of the place can placidly put up with such an apology for a road on the river front, when by a very small outlay it might indeed be made into a most desirable promenade. Naturally we enquired who was responsible for the roade ; the dragoman told us it was the Governor, mudir 1 think was the word he used ; another said it was the Municipality, but he as promptly sat upon, and told that there was no such body in Assiout; then a third very knowingly came forward, and said that it might be the Governor, but that he had no power left him to do anything, withont first consulting the Ministry of the Interior, or some such authority, generally represented in the provinces by young and inexperienced University men, and that under the circumstances the Governors preferred to temain inactive, drawing mean- while their pay, as any, seal on their part to ameliorate their districts would be promptly pat down by the young Inspectors. As we are rather sceptical about these views, we would he grateful for any enlightenment on the subject Meanwhile, might 1 beg those responsible for my sprained ankle (which, by the bye, prevent-ed my visiting the temples between Assiout and here) to ameliorate the cause of it, in liea of damages, which I could have claimed in a civilized country. Apologizing for taking up so muoh of your valuable space for a personal grievance, which might benefit others if my prayers to the proper authorities have any effect-- Yours painfally,
"A COMMON GARDEN TOURIST."
Luxor, January 25th.

div.head: CAIRO MUSEUM.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"

Sir,-- It seems incredible that the Museum should be closed for five consecutive says at this time of the year when the visitors' season is at its height.Two of my friends on their way to South Africa came purposely to cairo to see the Pyramids and the Museum, but had to leave without seeing the latter. three other friends were here during Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, and left on Sunday without being about to see the Museum. I feel sure these are not the only cases of dissappointment. I enclose my card, and remain, yours, etc,
A RESIDENT
Cairo, January 28.

div.head: VICTORIA COLLEGE.
div.p: To the Editor efr the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,—Mr. Secretary A. S. Preston, in his letter published in your issus of 26th inst, does not gainsay the facts stated in mine of previous date. He merely suggests that 1 should call at his office to have my facts set right, assuming of course they are not in order, whcoh might perhaps be the case in some unimportant particalar not affecting the principle involved. Without in the least wishing to enter into any controversy on this subject, I only want to know, not for my own information merely, but for that of the British public whose respect for the memory of our late Queen called the memorial into existence, why it is that imported material used in its con-struction is of non-British origin, a point upon I which the donors to the building have I think, a right to be informed.—Yours truly,
CASUAL OBSERVER.
ALEXANDRIA, JANUARY 28.

div.head: IS THIS A CAT-CH?
div.p: To the Editor of the ' Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,—While I was passing to-day at 2 p.m. through some lane in Paolino something, which made me sick at heart, stopped me. This was a tiny cat mewing and mewing over the top of a tree. I had to ask a servant—sitting at the door of a house near by—to get it down. The poor little thing was feeling cold, hungry, and miserable, T was told that the animal was being tormented in the morning by some wicked little boys. 1 would only draw the attention of the Alex. Sooiety for the Preven- tion of Cruelty to Animals to such things— Yours faithfully. ALEXANDRIAN.
Alexandria, Jan. 25th.

div.head: CRICKET.
div.p: ALEXANDRIA V. CARIO.

Played on Saturday and Ghezireh. Both sides were fairly well represented, though Alexandria lacked the services of Mustard, and Cairo were without Capt. Rome and several other more than useful cricketers. Alexandria won the toss and went in to bat at 11 a.m.. Marsden and M acLaren being the first pair, Wyatt and Sir F. Bathurst bowling. With six runs scored, MacLaren tried to pull a rising ball from Wyatt, and had to retire caught behind the wicket. The next ball swerved in the air and bowled H.P. Carver. In his next over Wyatt took two more wickets with successive balls. H B. Carver fell to a swerving yorker, end Peel to a fast good length ball, which he failed to time. Macaulay and Marsden then took the score to 29, when the former was bowled by Graves. Of the rest of the innings the less said the better ; except Marsden, who showed excellent defence throughout, no one could stay against Wyatt, and when Marsden was bowled by a beauty at 58 all chance of even a passable score was gone. At the same total McLean fell to a good long field catch by Capt. Liddell, and the innings was over. Wyatt, till now unlucky against Alexandria, had a great day. We have only once or twice seen him bowl better (considering his want of practice) and some of the balls he sent dowu took a lot of playing. Marsden played a very fne innings, only succumbing to a really good ball, and overyone was sorry that be did not carry his bat. At lunch time Cairo had made 58 for three wickets ; Alexandria were a little shakey in the slips to start with, Bathurst being let off early in his useful innings of 28 After lunch Capt. Liddell quickly put Cairo in a very comfortable position. His innings of 66 was in every way a fine effort. He bit very hard on the offside and numbered nine boundary hits and seven threes among his strokes. The remainder of the Cairo team were obviously inclined to live up to the adage, "A short life but a merry one," and gave the Alexandria outfields much to do. MacLaren and Carver made good catches and Barnard, besides effecting a characteristic catch in the slips, showed great courage in attempting the ' tour de force" of catching a big on-drive in the middle of his chest. Doubtless owing to an accident the ball rolled off, leaving a bruise to mark its impact and a grateful recollection of the event in the minds of the spectators. Sanderson made a useful debut, scoring 28 and keeping wicket well for Cairo. Dawson was not at his lest behind the sticks. In a poor light Alexandria fared badly in their second attempt, and when stumps were drawn seven of their wickets were down On the day's play Cairo were undoubtedly the better side, but a first innings of only 58 is ex- ceptional in Egyptian oricket. Score: --

div.head: GOLF.
div.p: Cairo has been a good deal enlivened the last few days by the arrival of our visitors from Alexandria. The football, cricket, and golf matches have been all keenly contested We hope that next year tennis requests and polo will be added to the list of competitors. The Alexandria sportsmen seem to be able to bold their own at most games. They are all good sportsmen. We welcomed their arrival, and deplore their departure. The football match proved most exciting, and after a keen struggle the game ended in a draw. In the cricket Cairo triumphed. Alexandria bad their revenge at golf. Below is the score : —

div.head: FOOTBALL.
div.p: CAIRO 5-A SIDE COMPETITION.

This competition took place on Wednesday and Thursday last. The first and second rounds were played on Wednesday. Eighteen teams entered, so to prevent byes coming in each round the first consisted of only two games. A sensational start was made, last year's winners, the Egyptian State Railway Inatitute "A" team, being easily beaten by 1st team "G" Coy. 2nd Innukilling Fusiliers by 3 goals to nil. The Institute "C" team made a good fight against H. Coy. of the Inniskillings but were defeated by a goal and a minor to nil.
1st Round.
1st team 'G" Coy. 2nd InniskilliDg Fusiliers, 3 goals.
"A" team Eg. State Railway Institute, nil.

Some interesting games were witnessed in the second ronnd, a strong wind not interferring much with the play. Quite the best match was the last game of the day, between the Royal Engineers' "A" team and "G" Coy. Innitkillings. Two replays were trade before a definite issue could be arrived at.

The third round produced some good matches. - a keen struggle taking place between "H" and "G" of ths Inniikillins', the former scoring a somewhat lucky goal just before time. The Army Service Corps and the band of the "Skins" 2nd team won their respective games in clever style. The 1st team of the band and the Military Police played very keenly, the former winning a fast game.

The semi finals ware keenly contested and very exciting.

The two band teams played an extremely fast game, the 1st team winning by a goal. The mach between "H" Coy. of the Inniskillings and the Army Service Corps was the best of the whole competition. "H" Coy. played a very good game and only the brilliant play of the corps goalkeeper, B. Jordan.kept them out. Gartland, the corps half back, worked like a Trojan. Three replays were necessary before a splendid combined movement by the corps towards ended in Baxter scoring with a beautiful shot. "H" Coy. worked hard to equalize, but Jordan and Gartland were impassible.
Semi-Finals.
1st team Band 2nd. Inniskilling Fusiliers 1goal.
2nd team Band 2nd Inniskilling Fusiliers nil.
Army Servioe Corps 1 goal 1 minor.
1st team "H" Coy. 2nd Inniskilling Fasiliers nil.

After a short rest the finalists turned out. It promised to be an easy victory for the band, as the corps were still a bit tired after their exertions in the semi-final. But to the delight of their supporters the crops made a determined attack at the very start and Baxter scored with a magnificent shot. The band made strenuous efforts to draw level but Jordan and Gartland kept their goal intact in magnifioent style. Time after time their fine efforts were applauded. The Army Servioe Corps well deserved their success. Messrs. J. S. Peacock and C. P. Richardeon refereed very efficiently, and pleased everybody with their decisions.
Final.
Army Service Corps 1 goal.
1st team Band 2nd Inniskilling Fusiliers nil.

The Earl and Countess of Cromer were present at the final and afterwards Lady Cromer presented the medals to the players, each of whom recieved a well-deserved ovation. Cheers were proposed and heartily given for the Earl and Countess of Cromer, C. Macauley Bey, and Mr. F. H Trevithick. The names of the medalists are : —
Gold :—Army Service Corps, Mr. B. Jordan, Corpl. Harman, Lo Corpl. Fowlea, Pte Gart land, and Pte L. Baxter.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: There will be two appointments for Doctors in the Sudan Medical Department made about April next.
Candidates should foward all t estimonials to the Director Sudan Medical Department, Khartoum.
Information as to age, qualifications, engagments since qualifications, is required.
Candidates should be about 25 years old and unmarried, and should have a good knowledge of English and Arabic. Egyptians will be preferred.
Salary to commence at the rate of L.E. 20 er mensem, eligible for increase after two years' satisfactory service.
Applicants should be prepared to appear for interview about the 2nd week in March 1907, in Cairo.
Appointment for probation 3 months, afterwards for a year before being permanently admitted inot the Government service.
Sudan Agency, War Office, Cairo.
ALexandria, January 17,1907.

Contrairement 1 l'attente générale, le marc'é de oa matin a été remarquablement aotif e' haussier. Un grand nombre de valeurs sont en reprise. De pin en plne demandés l'Agricole s'avan oe à 9 3fi, aveo beaucoup d'affaires et en ex oellente tendanoe. Elle est recherchée p r les gros portefeuilles. Il en est de même de l'Uuion F inoière qui est discrètement ramassés entre 6 1 /4 et 6 5/16. Ou a traité beaucoup d'affaires eu-Salt and Soda et Port Said Sait qui haussent respective- ment à 24/3 et 16/3, sur la rumeur, fondée ou non, d'une reprise des pourparlers de fusion. Autre rumeur : l'Urbaine aurti veudu à des oonditions fort avantageuses l'emplacement du Z'zinia et des Galeries Lafayette. Cent ce qui a fait mousser le titre de 7 5/16 à 7 13/16. Ce bruit a naturellement besoin de ooi.fir mation. Eu hausse encore la Cassa di Soonto à 280 l'anoieane et 2751a nouve'l",la Na'ional Bi k à 28 1/16, la Delta Light ill 3/4, les Divi le» des Tramways a 62, la D ia a 17 9/16, les Cotton Mills à G/6, les Nungovioh Hotels à 22 13/16. l'Investment à 1 5/16, les Splendid Ho- tels à 4 8/16, lë Comptoir à 7 15/16 l'aot-on anoienno et 7 9/16 la nouvelle et la Bu Iding Lands à 6 3/8. Par contre, 'a Bière du Caire reonle k 130 la Privilégiée fit 65 la Dividende, les Lo's Turos k 156, la Nile Lin i à 18 1/2, l'Ordinary Khédivial Mail k 31 1/2, ia part de fo dtteor Comptoir à 95, le Crédit Franco Egyptien a 6 5/16, la Banque i Orient à 133 1/2 et l'Antc- T.ansport k 4 9/4. L'action United reste inaotive k I 3/16, taudhqiesa fonda'eur est quelque pen échau gée aux environs de 8 1/2. La Levico repren I à 17/16 l'aotion et 20 la fmlatenr, avec affaires: La Hookar eit tonjours demandée à 11/4 L'Upper Egypt Hotels cote environ 5, prix nominal Le reste de la oote est sans ohangem mt. div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: To the Printers of Egypt.
div.p: SALISBURY SQUARE.
FLEET STREET, LONDON. E.C
Gentlemen,

Ten years ago we established in London the CAXTON TYPE FOUNDRY to manufacture Printing Types on the interchangable time and lobr-saving principles of Standard Point Line and Point Set on Point Body. We claimed, and have established the statement, that the exclusive use of Caxton Printing Types would save one-fourth of the compositiors time in the setting of all kinds of hand composition. At the present time onver 10,000 Printers in the United Kindom, Australasia, Canda, Africa, the Indian Empire and other British possessions are customers of the Caxton Type Foundry.
As is well known the type industry of America is controlled by a type TRUST, and in the Uniter Kingdon by a similar organization known as the type RING of British Type Manufacturers.

The CAXTON TYPE FOUNDRY was founded to oppose all such conmbinations. It is indpendent of all such connections, and is therefore, selling type at a lower price, and futhermore, guarantees to sell at the same price in all parts of the British Empire.

Another branch is the CAXTON WOOD MILLS, the largest and most complete Wood Working Plant in the British Empire exclusively employed in the production of space and labor=svaing woodwork for Printers. We have made a speciality of uding hard wood exclusively in all our productions. Wood Furniture and Reglet is made out of Tungstone, a specially close-grained Wood which is so heavy that is sinks in water and is therefore particularly valuable.

We are also makers of the widest and most complete range of PLATEN PRESSES in the World, comprising the well-known "Caxton" Platen, for fine work: the light-running "Swift" Platen for small printers: the Haddon "Improved Gordon," suitable for any jobbing printer: the Hadden "Saftey Platen" capable of printing 2,500 full formes per hour: the Haddon "Importved Victoria," modelled on the Cropper principle, but superior in construction and output.
We invite enquiries when complete Catalogues with all details will be sent post-free.
Yours faithfully,
JOHN HADDON & CO.
Agent for Egypt: JEFFERY W. EADY.
Chareh Montez, Boulevard Mohamed Aly, Cairo.

div.head: FRESKEL.

FRESKEL is a dry powdered preparation for Wall and Ceiling Decoration, made ready for use with the addition of water.
